content: so i was trying to get into the air national guard went to meps and took asvab and everything was fine. i came back from meps and my recruiter said that because i took my moms medicine when i was younger i was disqualified from air guard. my recruiter then told me to try navy or army so i was wondering if there is a way to get a waiver for this because i dont think its very fair that this is happening because i was a minor, i was taking it under my moms supervision and only took like two half pills and they were for headaches to see if it would help. ive heard of people getting waivers for marajuana and all that so i dont see why this is such a big deal especially since i was a minor under my moms supervision. by the way it wasnt meps that disqualified me it was the recruiters boss that said i was disqualified from the air guard so does this mean that im screwed or will i have a chance with the navy for this? ive never been in trouble i am in good health and good shape this is the only thing that is stopping me and its killing me because its so stupid!

content: Imitrex is prescribed for migranes and cluster headaches. You have a "history of" migranes hence your disqualification, from the Air National Guard. Google AR 40-501 Standards for Medical Fitness, Look at Chapter Two. Medical Standards are same for all branches,but waiver policies vary. Good Luck.
reply: Imitrex is prescribed for migranes and cluster headaches. You have a "history of" migranes hence your disqualification, from the Air National Guard. Google AR 40-501 Standards for Medical Fitness, Look at Chapter Two. Medical Standards are same for all branches,but waiver policies vary. Good Luck.

content: ya cept i dont have migraines my mom gave me the medicine to see if it would help and then later i went to the doctor who prescribed it to me just to see if that was the case but it wasnt and she already has written me a letter saying that it was not migraines it was just menstral headaches and if it was a migraine its not classical because it doesnt make me sick and i dont need the medicine because when she prescribed it to me i didnt take any and just used ibprofin if i started gettin a headache which doesnt work on migraines so its not migraines which is what she wrote in the letter but they wouldnt even give me a chance to give them the letter they just disqualified me for taking the medicine when i was younger
reply: ya cept i dont have migraines my mom gave me the medicine to see if it would help and then later i went to the doctor who prescribed it to me just to see if that was the case but it wasnt and she already has written me a letter saying that it was not migraines it was just menstral headaches and if it was a migraine its not classical because it doesnt make me sick and i dont need the medicine because when she prescribed it to me i didnt take any and just used ibprofin if i started gettin a headache which doesnt work on migraines so its not migraines which is what she wrote in the letter but they wouldnt even give me a chance to give them the letter they just disqualified me for taking the medicine when i was younger
title: can i get a waiver?

content: quote: Originally posted by 21306632: ya cept i dont have migraines my mom gave me the medicine to see if it would help and then later i went to the doctor who prescribed it to me just to see if that was the case but it wasnt and she already has written me a letter saying that it was not migraines it was just menstral headaches and if it was a migraine its not classical because it doesnt make me sick and i dont need the medicine because when she prescribed it to me i didnt take any and just used ibprofin if i started gettin a headache which doesnt work on migraines so its not migraines which is what she wrote in the letter but they wouldnt even give me a chance to give them the letter they just disqualified me for taking the medicine when i was younger Well, they should take your letter at MEPS, and consider it. But if your recruiter's boss doesn't want to play, he doesn't want to play. Consider trying another service or another recruiter. Migraines are disqualifying. Headaches in general can be dangerous in a military career. Not even tolerated in air crew positions. I get headaches myself, and it was tough in the Army, but you can never let that kind of thing affect you while on duty. If you can't damper the headache with an over-the-counter pain-killer and still drive on through a twelve to fourteen hour workday, in the hot sun trying to qualify on weapons, or standing guard, or staring at a little computer display, or sitting in a smelly diesel truck - all without complaining - then you don't have any business joining up. And you should be able to make it through basic training without anything. And it can still be migraines, even if it's treatable by ibuprofen, it's really a doc's call. If you CAN manage headaches with over-the-counter meds, and hack a long sucky workday, then maybe trying for the waiver is worth it.

Migraines are disqualifying. Headaches in general can be dangerous in a military career. Not even tolerated in air crew positions. I get headaches myself, and it was tough in the Army, but you can never let that kind of thing affect you while on duty. If you can't damper the headache with an over-the-counter pain-killer and still drive on through a twelve to fourteen hour workday, in the hot sun trying to qualify on weapons, or standing guard, or staring at a little computer display, or sitting in a smelly diesel truck - all without complaining - then you don't have any business joining up. And you should be able to make it through basic training without anything. And it can still be migraines, even if it's treatable by ibuprofen, it's really a doc's call. If you CAN manage headaches with over-the-counter meds, and hack a long sucky workday, then maybe trying for the waiver is worth it.
